articles.headline: Nurses and Doctors Speaking Out on Safety Now Risk Their Job
articles.snippet: Hospitals have warned, disciplined and even fired staff members who went public with workplace concerns about coronavirus precautions.
articles.abstract: Hospitals have warned, disciplined and even fired staff members who went public with workplace concerns about coronavirus precautions.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was the fliers bearing his photo that made Adam Witt suspect something had gone deeply wrong. Last week, Jersey Shore University Medical Center, where he worked as a nurse, posted the fliers at two security stations, declaring that he was persona non grata.
articles.byline: By Noam Scheiber and Brian M. Rosenthal

articles.headline: Small Businesses Wait for Cash as Disaster Loan Program Unravels
articles.snippet: Owners were supposed to be able to get up to $2 million. Now they’re being told the cap is $15,000 — if they can get any answers at all.
articles.abstract: Owners were supposed to be able to get up to $2 million. Now they’re being told the cap is $15,000 — if they can get any answers at all.
articles.lead_paragraph: Flooded by requests for help like never before, a federal disaster loan program that was supposed to deliver emergency relief to small businesses in just three days has run low on funding and nearly frozen up entirely. Now, business owners who applied are desperate for cash and answers about what aid, if any, they are going to receive.

articles.headline: Poultry Worker’s Death Highlights Spread of Coronavirus in Meat Plants
articles.snippet: Some employees are coming in sick, and one woman died after being ordered back to work. “Our work conditions are out of control,” a longtime Tyson employee said.
articles.abstract: Some employees are coming in sick, and one woman died after being ordered back to work. “Our work conditions are out of control,” a longtime Tyson employee said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Annie Grant, 55, had been feverish for two nights. Worried about the coronavirus outbreak, her adult children had begged her to stay home rather than return to the frigid poultry plant in Georgia where she had been on the packing line for nearly 15 years.
articles.byline: By Miriam Jordan and Caitlin Dickerson

articles.headline: OPEC and Russia Agree to Cut Oil Production
articles.snippet: The reductions for May and June were smaller than some investors and analysts had expected, and oil prices gave up earlier gains.
articles.abstract: The reductions for May and June were smaller than some investors and analysts had expected, and oil prices gave up earlier gains.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, Russia and other countries reached a tentative agreement on Thursday to temporarily cut production.

articles.headline: Trump Keeps Talking. Some Republicans Don’t Like What They’re Hearing.
articles.snippet: Aides and allies increasingly believe the president’s daily briefings are hurting him more than helping, and are urging him to let his medical experts take center stage.
articles.abstract: Aides and allies increasingly believe the president’s daily briefings are hurting him more than helping, and are urging him to let his medical experts take center stage.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In his daily briefings on the coronavirus, President Trump has brandished all the familiar tools in his rhetorical arsenal: belittling Democratic governors, demonizing the media, trading in innuendo and bulldozing over the guidance of experts.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Virus Throws Millions More Out of Work, and Washington Struggles to Keep Pace
articles.snippet: Federal efforts to keep businesses operating and workers employed have so far failed to stop the bleeding as the coronavirus tears through the economy in devastating ways.
articles.abstract: Federal efforts to keep businesses operating and workers employed have so far failed to stop the bleeding as the coronavirus tears through the economy in devastating ways.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the federal government began rushing trillions of dollars of assistance to Americans crushed by the coronavirus pandemic, the hope was that some of the aid would allow businesses to keep workers on the payroll and cushion employees against job losses.

articles.headline: For Students at a Lone School in California, Class Is Still On
articles.snippet: Out of the 10,521 public schools in California, Outside Creek is the only one with its doors open.
articles.abstract: Out of the 10,521 public schools in California, Outside Creek is the only one with its doors open.
articles.lead_paragraph: FARMERSVILLE, Calif. — At 7:45 on a recent morning, the strangest of scenes unfolded at Outside Creek Elementary: A school bus pulled up. Students stepped off and sauntered to class. The principal, Derrick Bravo, greeted a parent with a friendly hey-there handshake.
articles.byline: By Brian Wollitz and Ali DeFazio

articles.headline: Robots Welcome to Take Over, as Pandemic Accelerates Automation
articles.snippet: Broad unease about losing jobs to machines could dissipate as people focus on the benefits of minimizing close human contact.
articles.abstract: Broad unease about losing jobs to machines could dissipate as people focus on the benefits of minimizing close human contact.
articles.lead_paragraph: The recycling industry was already struggling before the pandemic. Now, an increasing number of cities are suspending recycling services, partly out of fear that workers might contract the coronavirus from one another while sorting through used water bottles, food containers and boxes.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and David Gelles

articles.headline: A New Front for Nationalism: The Global Battle Against a Virus
articles.snippet: Every country needs the same lifesaving tools. But a zero-sum mind-set among world leaders is jeopardizing access for all.
articles.abstract: Every country needs the same lifesaving tools. But a zero-sum mind-set among world leaders is jeopardizing access for all.
articles.lead_paragraph: As they battle a pandemic that has no regard for borders, the leaders of many of the world’s largest economies are in the thrall of unabashedly nationalist principles, undermining collective efforts to tame the novel coronavirus.
articles.byline: By Peter S. Goodman, Katie Thomas, Sui-Lee Wee and Jeffrey Gettleman

articles.headline: Childbirth in Venezuela, Where Women’s Deaths Are a State Secret
articles.snippet: We spent weeks following women inside the country’s health care system, which has been crippled by a broken economy overseen by an increasingly authoritarian government.
articles.abstract: We spent weeks following women inside the country’s health care system, which has been crippled by a broken economy overseen by an increasingly authoritarian government.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — The labor pains began in her village, in the dark.
articles.byline: By Julie Turkewitz, Isayen Herrera and Meridith Kohut

articles.headline: Burning Cell Towers, Out of Baseless Fear They Spread the Virus
articles.snippet: A conspiracy theory linking the spread of the coronavirus to 5G wireless technology has spurred more than 100 incidents this month, British officials said.
articles.abstract: A conspiracy theory linking the spread of the coronavirus to 5G wireless technology has spurred more than 100 incidents this month, British officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — On April 2, a wireless tower was set ablaze in Birmingham. The next day, a fire was reported at 10 p.m. at a telecommunications box in Liverpool. An hour later, an emergency call came in about another cell tower in Liverpool that was going up in flames.
articles.byline: By Adam Satariano and Davey Alba
